childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1974-1986

Children born in 1974 arrived in the same year a president left office in disgrace, though they'd have no memory of it. What they'd remember instead was the texture of what came after — the Ford and Carter years, that strange interregnum when America was trying to figure out what kind of country it wanted to be now that the old certainties had collapsed. Their parents were navigating this question at the kitchen table, arguing about gas prices and grocery bills while their children learned to crawl on shag carpet in rooms that smelled of cigarette smoke and Pledge furniture polish.

The economic anxiety of their early years was atmospheric and inescapable. Inflation was eroding paychecks. The energy crisis had rewritten the household budget. Fathers who had expected secure, lifelong employment were discovering that expectation was increasingly fictional. Mothers who had planned to stay home were finding that the mathematics of the late 1970s required a second income whether they wanted one or not. The family structure this cohort was born into — one parent at work, one parent at home — was giving way to something more improvised: two parents working, children fending for themselves, everyone adjusting to an arrangement nobody had quite chosen.

At five, the hostages were taken in Iran, and for more than a year the crisis played out on the evening news like a slow-motion national humiliation. Children didn't understand the geopolitics, but they understood the mood: frustration, impotence, the sense that the country was being pushed around and couldn't push back. At seven, Reagan took office and the mood shifted. The malaise was officially over, replaced by a brisk, business-suited optimism that children experienced as a change in household temperature — warmer, more confident, though whether the confidence was justified remained an open question.

School during the early 1980s was settling into a pattern that would define the decade. The experimental approaches of the previous era were gone. What remained was orderly, structured, and increasingly standardized. Desks faced forward. Teachers lectured. Tests measured what could be measured and ignored the rest. The gifted programs and tracking systems that sorted children into academic lanes were in full swing, and by third or fourth grade most children had a fairly clear sense of which lane they occupied. The system was efficient. Whether it was humane was a different question.

The Cold War, for this cohort, wasn't history — it was the wallpaper. Nuclear anxiety was so constant it had become almost banal. Drills were practiced without urgency. The threat was acknowledged without emotion. Children understood, in the vague way children understand anything abstract, that the world could end, that missiles existed, that the Soviet Union was the enemy. This information was filed alongside other adult concerns — taxes, mortgages, the check engine light — as something real but not immediately actionable. The fear was there. It had just been domesticated.

By twelve, the Challenger exploded on live television in classrooms across the country, and the domesticated fear suddenly had teeth again. The event landed differently on this cohort than on older children — they were old enough to understand what had happened but young enough that the emotional impact hit without the buffer of prior experience. It was their first encounter with the idea that watched events could be irreversible, that optimism could be punished, that the adults running complex systems could be catastrophically wrong. It was, in retrospect, the end of their childhood and the beginning of the worldview they'd carry into adulthood.

generational_identity.html:
The Gen X Generation

Generation X, born between 1965 and 1980. The name came from a Douglas Coupland novel, and it stuck because nobody could think of anything better. They're the middle child of American demographics—65 million people sandwiched between 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials. They've spent their entire life being overlooked, which suits them fine. They'd rather be underestimated than overhyped.

Nixon resigned four months after they were born. The defining characteristic of this generation is that nobody defined them at all. They were the first latchkey kids. Their parents were at work, or divorced, or both. They let themselves in after school with a key on a string around their neck, made their own Kraft mac and cheese, and watched reruns until someone came home. This wasn't neglect—it was the '70s. Free-range parenting before anyone named it. Authority figures lie, institutions fail, trust is earned, not given. It made them self-reliant in ways that border on pathological.

Their defining moment came at twelve: the Challenger exploded on live television. January 28, 1986. Christa McAuliffe, the teacher-astronaut, was supposed to inspire a generation. Instead, they watched the shuttle break apart seventy-three seconds after launch. The O-ring failed. The institution failed. They watched their teacher's face crumble, and they learned that even NASA could be catastrophically wrong, that heroes could die while they watched, that triumphant moments could end in tragedy without warning.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, they were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. This generation watched institutions fail in real-time. Watergate proved the president could be a criminal. Vietnam proved the government could lie about a war for a decade. The oil crisis proved that abundance wasn't guaranteed. Three Mile Island proved that technology could betray them. They learned early that authority figures were fallible, that systems were unreliable, that the only person they could really count on was themselves.

Gen X invented irony as a lifestyle. Sincerity was for suckers. Cool was not caring, or at least pretending not to. They perfected the art of the sardonic comment, the raised eyebrow, the whatever shrug. This was armor. If they didn't care, they couldn't be hurt. If they mocked everything, nothing could mock them first. They can still entertain themselves without a screen. That's a superpower now.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The Godfather Part II came out in 1974—proof that sequels could surpass originals, which Hollywood immediately forgot and spent the next fifty years failing to replicate. Chinatown taught audiences that sometimes the bad guys win. Blazing Saddles was offensive in ways that would get a movie canceled today. Young Frankenstein proved Mel Brooks could do anything. People magazine launched, beginning the celebrity industrial complex that would eventually consume all media.

Musically, 1974 was the year disco started its hostile takeover. Barry White was everywhere, growling about love in that impossibly deep voice. ABBA won Eurovision with 'Waterloo' and began their campaign to make every human on Earth know the words to 'Dancing Queen.' John Denver was singing about Rocky Mountain highs. KC and the Sunshine Band wanted booties shaken. The Ramones formed in a Queens basement, planting seeds for punk that wouldn't bloom until they were old enough to appreciate it.

At three, 'Saturday Night Fever' was danced to without understanding what any of it meant. At five, they probably owned a pair of those tiny Bee Gees-style white suits. At seven, 'Grease' had everyone convinced that high school would involve leather jackets and choreographed dance numbers. At ten, 'Thriller' changed everything—they remember exactly where they were when they first saw that video. Michael Jackson transformed in front of them, and so did music.

Childhood TV was Happy Days, Laverne & Shirley, and The Six Million Dollar Man. They wanted to be Steve Austin. The bionic sound effect was made when they ran. They probably asked for the action figure with the bionic eye they could look through. At eight, Dallas premiered, and suddenly everyone wanted to know who shot J.R. At eleven, Luke Skywalker learning the truth about his father was watched and something was felt in their chest that they still can't name.

Then MTV launched when they were seven. August 1, 1981. 'Video Killed the Radio Star' by the Buggles—the first video ever played on the network that would define their adolescence. By twelve, every word to 'Like a Virgin' was known, the Moonwalk could be done (badly), and opinions were had about whether Van Halen was better with David Lee Roth or Sammy Hagar. The answer was Roth. It's always Roth.

High school was The Breakfast Club, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, Pretty in Pink. John Hughes understood them in ways their parents never would. They saw themselves in those characters—the brain, the athlete, the basket case, the princess, the criminal. By the time they graduated, they'd transitioned to grunge. Nirvana's 'Nevermind' dropped when they were seventeen. Flannel wasn't just fashion—it was identity. They smelled like teen spirit whether they wanted to or not.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The sound of a rotary phone is burned into muscle memory. That satisfying resistance as the dial was dragged around, the whirr as it returned. If someone's number had a lot of 9s and 0s, they actually had to want to call them. Long distance cost money, so it was kept brief. 'It's expensive!' moms would yell from the kitchen. They learned to communicate efficiently.

At three, first VCR demonstrations were probably watched at department stores. The idea of recording television was science fiction. At six, families might have gotten one—a top-loader the size of a small suitcase, with a wired remote on a twenty-foot cable. By eight, the blinking 12:00 was mastered. Nobody else in the family could program it. This was their first taste of technological superiority over adults.

Atari changed everything. They were five when the 2600 launched, and suddenly the TV wasn't just for watching—it was for doing. Pong was two rectangles and a square, but it was mesmerizing. Combat. Space Invaders. Pitfall. Pac-Man (the terrible home version). They played until thumbs blistered. Cartridges were blown on when they wouldn't work. They learned that hitting things sometimes fixed them.

At nine, the IBM PC arrived. At eleven, Apple ran the '1984' Super Bowl commercial. At thirteen, they were probably in computer labs learning BASIC on machines that cost more than their parents' car. PRINT 'HELLO WORLD.' FOR/NEXT loops. The cursor blinking green on black, waiting for them to tell it what to do. This was power.

They were twenty-one when the World Wide Web went public. Twenty-four when Amazon launched. Twenty-six when Google started. Thirty when Facebook opened. Thirty-three when the iPhone arrived. They didn't grow up with the internet—they watched it being built. They remember life before email, before URLs, before everything was connected. This gives them perspective that younger generations can't access.

They're the bridge generation. They can explain modems to Boomers and TikTok to their kids. They remember when 'logging on' was an event, when dial-up had to screech its handshake, when a single image could take minutes to load. They use technology as a tool, not a habitat. They can put their phone down. They know what boredom feels like. These are superpowers now.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

Nixon resigned four months after they were born—August 8, 1974. Parents watched it live, the only president in American history to quit the job. Gerald Ford took over and promptly pardoned Nixon, teaching them before they could walk that the powerful play by different rules. They don't remember any of it, but the cynicism seeped into the water supply.

At one, Saigon fell. The Vietnam War ended with helicopters evacuating the embassy roof, with desperate people clinging to skids. They don't remember it, but the veterans were everywhere—uncles, neighbors, guys at the gas station who seemed older than they were. The war shaped their parents. Its aftermath shaped them.

At three, Elvis died. They don't remember that either, but they know the footage—the crowds at Graceland, the weeping fans, the drug-bloated body discovered by his girlfriend. The King was dead at forty-two. Rock and roll's first warning about excess.

At five, the Iran hostage crisis began. For 444 days, Americans were held captive—a nightly reminder that American power had limits.

At seven, Ronald Reagan was shot outside the Washington Hilton. At eight, John Lennon was murdered outside the Dakota. At twelve, the Challenger disaster became their generation's shared trauma—the shuttle broke apart while classrooms across America watched live.

At fifteen, the Berlin Wall fell. November 9, 1989. It was watched live—crowds with sledgehammers, champagne, tears. The Cold War that had defined their entire childhood just... ended. The threat that made them practice hiding under desks evaporated. They were supposed to feel relief. Mostly, they felt disoriented. What is there to worry about when the apocalypse gets canceled?

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, they were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. They were probably at work. They were old enough to have a career, maybe a mortgage, possibly kids. Old enough to understand that the world had fundamentally changed, that the peace dividend was over, that a new era of permanent anxiety had begun. At thirty-four, the financial system collapsed. At forty-six, a pandemic shut down the world. They've lived through more 'unprecedented' events than their parents' generation saw in their entire lives.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

The job market of 1992-1996 offered opportunities to negotiate salary because employers needed workers. The economy was expanding. The internet was creating jobs that hadn't existed five years earlier. Unemployment was low. Optimism was high. They could be picky.

This generation watched the social contract between employers and employees get shredded, but they caught the tail end of when it still meant something. They started their career when pensions still existed, when health insurance was expected, when 'company loyalty' wasn't yet an oxymoron. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. They'll end it in the gig economy, dependent on a 401(k) that moves with the market's mood.

The dot-com boom made everyone feel like a genius. They were twenty-five when Amazon IPO'd. Twenty-six when Google launched. They probably knew someone who got rich on stock options. They might have been that someone. They definitely watched the bubble inflate, participated in the irrational exuberance, believed that this time was different. Then March 2000 happened, and trillions evaporated. Job security became an oxymoron. The bust taught them that disruption usually means someone's about to get disrupted out of a job.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis arrived. Now they're in leadership positions—VP, Director, maybe C-suite if they played their cards right. They're sandwiched between Boomers who refuse to retire and Millennials who want to work differently. They're the translator, explaining each generation to the other while trying to get actual work done. Boomers want face time and hierarchy. Millennials want flexibility and meaning. They just want everyone to answer their emails.

Their management style was shaped by terrible managers. They had bosses who took credit for their work, others who micromanaged everything, others who got promoted for being loud rather than competent. They learned what not to do. They value competence over credentials, results over process. They're suspicious of corporate speak, team-building exercises, and anyone who uses 'synergy' without irony.

COVID proved they could work from anywhere, which means now they're expected to work from everywhere. The office is in their pocket. The boundary between work and life isn't blurred—it's gone. They're answering Slack at midnight, taking calls on vacation, always available because that's what availability means now. They adapted. They always adapt. That's the problem.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember when having a crush meant memorizing locker combinations, class schedules, the exact moment they'd walk past the water fountain? When getting phone numbers required asking—out loud, in person, with witnesses? When calling meant talking to dads first, who definitely didn't approve of whatever was about?

Gen X is the last generation to date entirely offline. They met people at parties, at bars, through friends, at work. Phone numbers were asked for on napkins. They waited by the phone—the landline, attached to the wall, with a cord stretched into closets for privacy. No caller ID. Every ring was a possibility. The anticipation was half the romance.

They probably got married in their mid-to-late twenties. The average age at first marriage for this cohort was 26 for men, 24 for women—later than Boomers, earlier than Millennials. Divorce rates peaked just before they hit marrying age, so they'd seen what happened when marriages failed. Many of them lived it. Children of divorce recognize each other. The shared understanding doesn't need words.

This generation quietly normalized couples therapy. They read the books—Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus. The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People. Everything Oprah recommended. They talked about feelings, which their parents never did. They did 'the work,' which is a phrase that would have confused their grandparents entirely. Relationships were projects that required maintenance. They maintained.

Communication evolved dramatically during their adult life. They went from landlines to car phones (that bag in the trunk) to flip phones to smartphones. From letters to email to texts to DMs. They remember when a phone call was the default and a letter was special. Now a phone call is intrusive and nobody writes letters. They adapted to every new platform, but part of them still thinks voice is more personal than text.

Their friendships are low-maintenance by design. They have group chats with people they've known for thirty years. They can go months without talking and pick up exactly where they left off. Gen X friendship doesn't require constant maintenance. They're all too busy, too scattered, too independent for that. They show up when it matters. That's enough.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

They grew up during stagflation—the worst of both worlds. High inflation. High unemployment. Parents talked about money constantly because there never seemed to be enough. Gas lines. Layoffs. The 'malaise' speech. WIN buttons ('Whip Inflation Now'—they didn't). Mortgage rates hit 18% in 1981. They learned early that economic security was a polite fiction.

But then they caught a break. They entered the workforce when houses were affordable—median price around $120,000 in 1995, when starting salaries might have been $25,000-40,000. The math worked. Down payments could be saved for. Something could actually be bought. This wasn't virtue. It was timing. They happened to be the right age when prices hadn't yet gone insane.

Three major economic crashes hit during their prime earning years. The 2008 crisis hit them mid-career. They were thirty-four, probably with a mortgage, maybe kids, definitely a 401(k) that had been doing well. Then Lehman collapsed and everything followed. The market dropped 40%. Retirement accounts were watched crater. Friends losing houses were watched. Banks getting bailed out while homeowners got austerity were watched. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. The lesson was the same one Watergate taught: the system protects its own.

They got 401(k)s instead of pensions, which was a worse deal but still a deal. They're the last generation that could build wealth through conventional means. Job security became an oxymoron. The safety net was already fraying when they reached for it, but at least it was still there.

Their relationship with money is practical to the point of paranoia. They save because they've seen how fast things collapse. They're skeptical of bubbles—dot-com, housing, crypto—because they've watched them pop. They don't trust that anything will last. They probably have more in savings than strictly necessary, because 'strictly necessary' depends on whether the floor holds.

They're the generation that will inherit from Boomers—the largest intergenerational wealth transfer in history. Some of them will receive significant inheritances. Many won't. The gap between prosperous Gen Xers and struggling ones will widen. This generation's financial story isn't one story. It's two: those who caught the last wave and those who didn't.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This generation's greatest strength is their greatest weakness: independence that curdles into isolation. They're so used to figuring things out alone that they don't ask for help when they need it. They don't burden others. They handle it. They've always handled it. This is admirable until it becomes pathological—until they're drowning and too proud to wave.

They've perfected the art of not caring, or pretending not to. Ironic detachment was their survival mechanism. Sincerity felt dangerous, so they armored themselves with sarcasm. The problem is that armor keeps things out and in. They can critique everything and commit to nothing. They're so busy being too cool to try that they miss opportunities for genuine engagement.

This generation is invisible in ways that have cost them. They're not large enough to dominate like Boomers. They're not young enough to represent the future like Millennials and Gen Z. Policy debates happen around them, not about them. Marketing ignores them. Politicians don't court their vote the way they court everyone else's. They've adapted to being overlooked, but adaptation isn't acceptance.

They're cynical about institutions in ways that become self-defeating. Voting seems pointless, so they don't vote, which makes it actually pointless. Organizing seems futile, so they don't organize, which makes change less likely. Their skepticism is earned—they watched every institution fail—but it's also a cage. Sometimes cynicism is just giving up with extra steps.

They've normalized overwork as identity. They invented 'work hard, play hard,' which meant 'work hard, then work more.' They measure themselves by productivity. They don't know how to rest without guilt. Vacation feels like truancy. They've confused exhaustion with virtue. Millennials get criticized for hustle culture, but Gen X built the prototype. Millennials just branded it.

And here's the deepest blind spot: they've mistaken going it alone for strength. Their latchkey independence became a philosophy. But no one succeeds entirely alone, and refusing help isn't self-reliance—it's just isolation with better PR. The kid with the key around their neck grew up, but they never fully learned to ask for what they need.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Their 20s (1994-2004): The timing was perfect. The economy expanded. Jobs were available. They could negotiate because employers needed them. Some of them rode the dot-com rocket—stock options, IPO dreams, the fantasy that this time was different. Then March 2000, and trillions vanished. They learned that markets lie. But they were young enough to recover, and there was time. Their twenties were the last decade when optimism still made sense.

Their 30s (2004-2014): They hit their stride and then the floor collapsed. The 2008 crisis gutted everything. Houses underwater. Retirement accounts halved. Friends laid off, foreclosed, broken. The recovery was slow and uneven, and if they kept their job, they felt grateful in ways that embarrassed them. They had kids, mortgages, responsibilities. They learned that the economy could betray them at any age. They also learned resilience, because what choice did they have?

Their 40s (2014-2024): This is where they are now, or just finishing. Peak earning years, peak responsibility years. Kids are teenagers or launched. Parents are aging, needing more. They're sandwiched—managing up and down, responsible for everyone, seen by no one. They have authority at work but wonder if the young people respect them or just tolerate them. They have perspective but no one asks for it.

Their 50s (2024-2034): The next decade. Kids will be independent, or independent-ish. Parents may be gone or going. They'll have more time and less energy—the cruelest trade life offers. Retirement will start feeling real instead of theoretical. They'll calculate whether they have enough. The answer will probably be 'maybe, if nothing goes wrong.' Nothing has ever gone wrong, they'll tell themselves, knowing that's not true.

Their 60s and beyond (2034+): Retirement, if they can afford it. Social Security will probably exist but pay less. Medicare will probably exist but cover less. The world will be unrecognizable—climate changed, technology advanced, demographics shifted. They'll tell younger people about rotary phones and three TV channels and video stores. They'll think they're describing ancient history. They won't entirely disagree.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US in 1974. They're the demographic valley between two peaks, which explains why no one markets to them and everyone forgets they exist. Part of roughly 65 million Gen Xers, sandwiched between 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): Boomers got pensions and the social contract intact. They expected loyalty from employers and received it. They lecture Gen X about work ethic from houses that appreciated 400% while they slept. The difference isn't values—it's timing. Boomers happened to be born into abundance. Gen X happened to catch its tail end.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): Gen X had it easier economically but harder emotionally. They could still get jobs that came with benefits. But they had less support—nobody worried about their self-esteem, nobody gave them participation trophies, nobody scheduled their playdates. They were expected to figure it out, and they did, but the figuring left marks.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Gen X is practically ancient. Gen Z has never known a world without smartphones. Gen X remembers rotary phones. Gen Z has never known economic stability. Gen X remembers when jobs came with pensions. Gen X bridges the analog and digital worlds in ways Gen Z can't understand because they only know one side. Gen Z is anxious in ways that make sense; the world has given them nothing to trust. Gen X is cynical for the same reasons, just differently expressed.

Gen X life expectancy is 76-78 years—slightly lower than Boomers due to the usual suspects: stress, lifestyle, healthcare costs. They'll work longer than their parents did, retire later if at all. The traditional life script was available to them in ways it isn't for later generations, but they were already watching it fray. They're the transition generation—they got some of the benefits and all of the anxiety.

They didn't complain about it—they just did the work. That's their legacy: competence without fanfare. They're the forgotten generation, and they've made peace with it. They never wanted the spotlight anyway. They'd rather be underestimated and effective than celebrated and scrutinized. They can still entertain themselves without a screen. That's a superpower now.

year_events: The Godfather Part II proved sequels could be art
Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruth's home run record
The first UPC barcode was scanned
